file_content.text: I'm not sure who you are. That disturbs me.
You won't make it out of this. No one ever does.
Guess that's done. I'd kick around his body, but the bomb in his head might go off.
Too bad he decided to play you. If he'd dealt straight, bet he could've told us Keeper's real name.
Keeper's not the only one he could've exposed.
He knew your secrets.
A lot of people know my secrets. I get around. But no one knows it all.
He missed his chance. I have no pity for him.
His mistake.
Yeah. For a guy who thought so much of himself, he wasn't really that smart.
I was hoping to kill him anyway.
I'm glad he fought us.
Well, sure. Eventually.
Cipher Nine, this is Watcher Two. Please respond.
I need a status update on Watcher X. I'm ready to put out a general alert.
The situation is resolved. Watcher X is dead.
No need for that.
I found him. We talked. He didn't last.
He wasn't any trouble.
That's... that's excellent news. Well done.
Enjoy the sight--one dead, genetically enhanced former Watcher.
Look for yourself.
I... see. Very well. That's all the evidence I need.
I'll downgrade our security status. Operations will proceed as normal.
For the record, Cipher--I don't enjoy violence. But I'm extremely happy that Watcher X is out of commission.
Why does he bother you so much?
You're serious?
We had nearly the same training. But he was better than me. Smarter. I... know what he was capable of.
I was hoping to bring him back to Shadow Town.
I didn't want him dead.
Then frankly, I'm glad the situation forced your hand.
Sounds like there's some violence you do enjoy.
Hypocrite.
I appreciate the outcome. That's all.
I'll send a crew to collect Watcher X's corpse; his mind and body are Imperial technology.
Consider the matter closed. Records of his presence here will be erased, and you're not to speak of this further. I'll debrief you back at the ship.
Look around. Note your target. Check him for weapons--held, concealed, improvised.
Now scan the rest of the area. Does he have allies? Are they hiding? Are you outmatched without realizing?
I'm disappointed in you, Cipher. I offered you information that could have given you power over your masters.
I knew what I was doing when I took this job.
I'm a loyal agent.
So many operatives say that.
You might be right--but I don't trust your information.
You're not a reliable source.
My fault, maybe. I should've shown you the codes. Pity.
Finally, we get to fight.
I'm sure you are.
I owe you my release, but I have no qualms about us fighting. If you'd like to back out, you may.
It's too late--for both of us.
I won't.
As you like.
This only ends peacefully if you go back to Shadow Town.
You can still surrender.
I won't do that.
If I let you go now, the Watchers will know.
Intelligence won't let me.
True. Which would make working with them untenable. I understand.
Goodbye, agent. Now we reach the end.
Congratulations, Cipher. You've struck the final blow to the terror cell.
Survivors will be unable to regroup. Ties to the Eagle's network have been severed. There's only one catch.
Destroying the network hub sent a ripple through the HoloNet. Shadow Town security momentarily failed. I took the opportunity to escape.
Escaping was your real goal all along.
You planned this.
I knew working with Intelligence would expand my options. It wasn't until we met that I formulated a plan.
If that's true, why bother telling me?
I don't understand.
I'll kill you.
Your anger is understandable. Keep it in check.
Damn son of a sow....
Soon, one of your Watchers will notice the glitch. You'll be asked to find me. Hunt me. But I don't want you as an enemy.
Tell your Watcher that I remain imprisoned. Once I'm safe, I'll share my secrets. You'll know everything Intelligence keeps from its Ciphers.
What kind of information are we talking about?
I'm listening.
How do I know you'd keep your end of the deal?
I should trust you?
You don't. But consider the possibilities.
You can't bribe me.
You're not thinking clearly.
Do you want the details of the eugenics program that bred myself and Watcher Two? The aliases of your "friend" Kaliyo Djannis?
You sleazy freak. Think you can play? You're dead. You're so dead.
It's yours. All the secrets. You only have to help me escape Nar Shaddaa.
If you think you can turn me, you're wasting your time.
Not a chance.
You know how to make a tempting offer.
I'm intrigued.
I can guarantee this chance won't come again.
You're kidding, right? You're going to sit back and let him use you?
Whether he escapes shouldn't matter to you. Why do you care?
Why so angry?
I have my reasons, Kaliyo. Don't question them.
It's my decision.
This guy thinks he can play us. No one does that to me. You get that? Not your bosses, and not some purebred garbage.
Is there something you don't want me to know?
Worried about your secrets?
I don't care what he tells you. I care that he thinks he can get away with manipulating us.
Apologies for interrupting. I have to get to my ship, and you have an incoming call from your masters.
I'll hunt you down, you smug creep.
You scum.
I'm sorry you feel that way.
Now I should be going. I have to get to my ship; you have an incoming call from your masters.
Goodbye, Cipher.
Cipher Nine? This is Watcher Two. I'm routing this call through a half-dozen city subsystems.
We intercepted a set of terrorist transmissions reporting the destruction of a company called "VerveGen."
I've sent agents to scour the company's systems for additional data. It seems the Nar Shaddaa cell has been neutralized.
I just destroyed the cell's communications hub. It could have salvageable data.
Check my location, too.
I'll alert the teams. There's also something else.
I can confirm that the cell's been destroyed.
Situation is resolved.
That's excellent. But there's something that concerns me.
Sorry--barely caught that. If you've got something to say, say it fast.
Uh, I'm losing you.
Understood. Increasing signal strength.
As I was monitoring, I noticed some unusual network activity. It's possible Shadow Town's security was breached.
I'm worried about Watcher X. He'd take advantage of a fault like that.
That's what I was about to report. He called me before you did.
It's already a problem.
I'm going after him now. He called me to gloat.
I'll take care of him.
Damn it all. We can't have a rogue Watcher loose in the galaxy.
Head for the spaceport. I'll try to delay any departures--but be fast. Nar Shaddaa doesn't acknowledge Imperial authority.
Don't worry--he's not getting out of the city.
Already working on it.
It's good to hear you say that. Watcher Two out.
You're really worried about this, aren't you?
Are you okay?
Watcher X unnerves me. Do whatever you can; Watcher Two out.
Just let me do my job.
I won't distract you further. Watcher Two out.
That's the spirit. Let's kill that filth.
I just talked to him. He's still locked up.
There wasn't any breach.
I... must have made a mistake, then.
That man puts me on edge--I'm sorry you had to work with him.
You don't need to apologize.
It's alright.
Thank you... but my judgment may have been clouded.
You're not the only one who's bothered by him.
Me, too.
And I'm sure you had it worse than I did.
Learn to focus on your job--not your feelings.
Stay professional.
Keeping a rogue Watcher from running loose in the galaxy is part of my job.
I won't trouble you further. I'm knee-deep in new data, and I'm sure you have business left on Nar Shaddaa.
Contact me once you've returned to your ship. Watcher Two out.
You cowardly piece of filth. I'm not going to forget this.
Get to the communications hub in Network Access. End this.
Excellent work. The terrorists are dead.
There's nothing more we can do here. Get to VerveGen and intercept the terror cell leaders.
VerveGen's day-to-day management is expecting a visit from the owners. That's when the Cyclone will be turned over.
Security will increase--employees sent home, holocams activated, internal defenses powered on. But get into the meeting unnoticed and you'll find the terror cell leaders.
Then we can eliminate the terrorists and destroy the Cyclone.
Time for an ambush.
An appropriate solution. But the approach will require delicacy.
Going unnoticed is my specialty.
I can be careful.
I'm aware of that. But even Ciphers have their limits.
It's about time you came up with something useful.
Finally, some progress.
I'm glad you approve.
With effort, we can create a cybernetic disguise combining armor, implants and holographic technology. You would appear to be a class-five droid.
Most security devices don't screen mindless droid workers. Fitted with such a camouflage system, you could walk into VerveGen unmolested.
How do we get this working?
All right.
Being covered in cybernetics and holograms doesn't exactly sound healthy.
Is that safe?
It should be safe. Granted, I haven't seen it tested.
You expect me to go undercover as a droid?
Are you joking?
It's the most efficient way to get inside VerveGen. More to the point, it's the only way I can think of.
I've already assembled the system's components. All that remains is to implant the cybernetics necessary to hide your life readings.
I can put you to sleep with an anesthetic before making the incisions. Otherwise, we can begin; the procedure should be swift.
Just wake me up when the operation's done.
Put me to sleep.
Is all that really necessary?
I'm not sure about this.
The implants are smaller than blaster cartridges. The disguise is needed. Really--there's no need to be squeamish.
Now, awake or asleep?
I'll go to sleep, but this had better work.
Put me out.
Of course. I'll try not to cause any damage while I'm inside.
Not that I doubt him, but I'll keep an eye out for you. 'Night.
Keep an eye on him. If anything goes wrong...
Kaliyo? Watch over me.
I've got my blaster out.
Finished. I've inserted three implants along your spinal column. You'll never feel them.
If we're going to do this, I want to see what's happening.
Keep me awake.
There's no way I'm letting you knock me out.
Absolutely no anesthetic.
As you like. I'll go as fast as possible.
There. I've inserted three implants along your spinal column. The pain should fade quickly.
Congratulations. From now on, you'll be able to pass as a machine.
We're losing time. What's next?
Let's move.
A droid disguise... just what I've always wanted.
That's so weird.
This is it?
We're finished. Time to move on.
It won't be long before the cell leaders arrive at VerveGen. I suggest you get to the meeting. Eliminate everyone.
Afterward, I'll contact you for confirmation. Good luck, Cipher.
Welcome back, Cipher. Glad you could visit.
Most people in Shadow Town seek escape. Spies. Assassins. Freedom is the only reason they'd help the Empire.
But Imperial Intelligence isn't offering me freedom. You know why?
I was wondering about that.
Tell me.
I won't get sidetracked. Let's talk about VerveGen.
My only concern is our work.
If you insist.
You're insane. Letting you free would be the worst thing we could do.
Intelligence isn't stupid.
Imperial Intelligence is scared to let me free. But the Watchers know that if I refuse to help, my mental conditioning reacts.
If I disobey a superior, I get headaches. They last for days. So I may as well help you--the alternative is less pleasant.
Has Intelligence done that to anyone else?
Is that "conditioning" common?
Oh, yes. But I know you're eager to get back to business.
For what it's worth, you have my sympathy.
I'm sorry.
I wasn't looking for pity. I thought you might be interested.
Whatever it takes to keep you under control.
Good to know.
Me, or anyone else your employers want to train.
Now that we have surveillance, I've been able to monitor VerveGen's activities. The results are enlightening.
As we suspected, they're manufacturing Cyclone. In fact, VerveGen is preparing a large quantity of serum for transport and distribution.
They're transferring the Cyclone to other cells in the network.
Terrorists at work.
That's exactly right.
What else?
They weren't testing it out in the name of science.
I could've guessed that.
I won't argue. But this next point is more intriguing.
I need those terminals disabled if I'm going to set up surveillance around VerveGen.
Hello, Cipher. Always pleasant to speak.
You know, I managed to slice into the Star Cluster's holocams. I got to see how you handle field work.
Got yourself an admirer.
You had Jordel Tlan rather taken with you. Congratulations. I didn't think it possible to seduce a man like that.
Men like him aren't hard to manipulate.
It was easy.
I didn't think it possible to talk through a meeting with Jordel Tlan. You handled yourself adeptly.
See? And you thought I'd need to poison him.
No violence required.
It seems I was mistaken.
You handled the Twi'lek woman expertly. I underestimated your persuasiveness.
She was happy to share what she knew.
It was easy.
Seduction is a useful tool for you. Does that cause friction with other operatives? No matter.
You had no business watching me.
You violated my privacy.
There's no privacy in this work. At least I tell you when I'm watching.
Your questioning of Jordel Tlan was adeptly handled. You should try torturing people more often.
Let's talk about the mission, please.
Can we move on?
Of course. That's why I'm here.
I learned what I needed to learn.
It was necessary.
Poisoning Tlan was blackmail. Nothing more, nothing else.
It wasn't torture... exactly.
An important distinction. I apologize.
So. Now we know about VerveGen--a Synchet Industries medical subsidiary purchased by a shadowy group of buyers.
Those buyers were presumably members of the terror cell. The company was acquired to produce Cyclone and other technologies.
I reached the same conclusion.
Agreed.
How could terrorists afford to buy a company?
How's that possible?
Uncertain. It appears the Eagle's network has significant financial resources.
I understand you dealt with the financiers on Alderaan. You'd know the details better than I.
We need to take on VerveGen.
They're our next target.
Not yet. Soon, but not yet.
I've located the VerveGen offices, but I'm unable to obtain personnel records. Their data is very well secured.
I need you to set up surveillance. Slice into public terminals around the building perimeter, and I can use HoloNet resources to see and hear inside.
Say we're successful--then what?
And after that?
We analyze the situation. Determine our best approach.
All right.
They're unprepared. Can't we just wipe the place out?
We should attack now.
We have one chance to destroy VerveGen's operations. If we attack without knowing the facts, we risk cell leaders escaping.
VerveGen is located in the upper level industrial sites. The sector is overrun by corporate security--some may carry Cyclone as a last resort.
When you're done, come to Shadow Town. We'll meet in person. Watcher X out.
This isn't the place for you. Get to the Star Cluster Casino and investigate Jordel Tlan.
I have a corporate match. Cyclone's coding process is registered to Synchet Industries.
Synchet used to manufacture droids, food supplements, medical supplies. But Synchet declared bankruptcy five years ago. The company is gone.
In that case, where's the serum coming from?
What?
Someone else must be using their technology.
Not entirely, it seems.
I should've known Cyclone was a dead end.
You messed up.
Synchet--a dead company--is connected to Cyclone. Cyclone is connected to the terror cell... we need more.
I'm finding one former Synchet executive currently on Nar Shaddaa. He left the company just before it dissolved.
Question him about Synchet. We need to know what happened to their resources, whether they had terrorist connections.
Shouldn't be hard to interrogate a rich businessman.
He'll talk to me.
I'll do it.
If he's involved, he's dead.
He better hope he's innocent.
Is that what Imperial Intelligence teaches now? Wasteful.
Your executive is named Jordel Tlan. Rich, eccentric, reclusive. Stays in his private casino lounge. Only associates with droids.
No visitors allowed. No weapons allowed. He'll need a reason to talk to you--to be desperate to talk to you.
I'm not sure I care to hear your plan.
Do I even want to know?
I assume you have something in mind?
What're you thinking?
I know how to make men desperate for me.
Seduction, maybe?
I doubt Tlan is tempted by flesh. He's been with his droids too long.
Somehow, I don't like where this is going.
That doesn't sound good.
Is there a way to blackmail him?
What's our leverage?
I think so.
Use the resources you have. See those medical crates? Combine their chemicals correctly and you'll have an undetectable poison.
Tlan's serving droids won't notice if you poison his drink. When he sweats and chokes, offer the antidote in return for cooperation.
I'll do what I have to--but I make the call myself.
I'll keep my options open.
If you like.
Good thinking.
That's sick.
Think you can talk your way into a meeting? Good luck persuading his droids.
I'm sending the formulas for poison and antidote. The important thing is to get to Tlan. Get him talking about the terrorists, Cyclone and the dissolution of Synchet.
Hello again, Cipher. I'm seeing everything the bioscan sees.
Blood. Genetic codes. Who did this sample come from? I think it was an Evocii.
Genetic bonding agents. Molecular webs. Pure, perfect--take Cyclone and it becomes you.
I'm going deeper, now, Cipher. Looking for a signature to tell us who the artist is. Curious?
I'll play along. What've you found?
Sure, I'm curious.
This serum is "art" to you?
The "artist"?
Of a sort. It's not hard to appreciate when you see the intricacies.
I'm interested in tracing Cyclone to the terrorists. Nothing else.
Only if it helps us.
You're very dedicated. Keeper must be pleased.
You should be in the Duros Sector. You shouldn't be talking to me.
This is Watcher X. I've been waiting for your call.
I assume you have my Cyclone specimen. Was there any trouble at the augmentations shop? Did you admire their work?
I have the serum. The shop's been dealt with.
Mission complete.
I saw what went on in there.
Their work was... something.
Crude, but inspired. Not as artful as what the Empire did to me. Not as skillful as what they did to Watcher Two.
Don't waste my time asking stupid questions.
Stick to the point.
Am I being unprofessional? Maybe I've forgotten how a Watcher should act. It's been a long time.
Now--we need to analyze the specimen. Figure out where Cyclone comes from. We'll need equipment I can't buy in Shadow Town.
There's an abandoned medical laboratory in the Duros Sector. If armed refugees haven't stripped it bare, you can run the analysis at the lab's bioscan.
What happens once I get the analysis?
Then what?
You send the results to me. Then I think about Cyclone's connection to the terrorists. I'm very good at thinking.
Will these "armed refugees" pose a problem?
What about refugees?
I don't see why. You're a trained killer. Kill them.
You better not be giving me the runaround.
I'm tired of running errands.
Why would I do that? If you couldn't trust me, why would Imperial Intelligence give us this assignment?
Get the Cyclone specimen. It's the only way to trace the serum to the terrorists.
Step inside. Scan the apartment for the important things: overt threats, escape routes, access terminals.
Take your time.
Now look again. Scan for concealed weapons. Hiding places. Anything innocent is probably a bug; anything you don't recognize should be analyzed later. Play the game--I can wait.
Are you Watcher X?
Hello.
Yes. Formerly Watcher Five. Formerly Minder Eight. Not that you're authorized to know it.
What are you talking about?
Huh?
The systems of Imperial Intelligence. The training. Be vigilant--because if you aren't, you die.
Nice meeting you, too, Watcher X.
You're not much of a host.
I apologize. "I'm so glad to see you." Is that what you were expecting?
Got a lot of brass for someone living in filth.
You're a Cipher agent. Specializations in disguise, seduction, infiltration, assassination.
You're brave to come to Shadow Town. This could be your future--a bomb in your head, trapped here like a criminal.
Stop stalling and start helping. Now.
We have business.
Of course. Watcher Two--my "sister" in the eugenics program--told me what you need.
I'm still not completely clear what this place is.
Tell me about Shadow Town.
The people in the slum are spies, assassins, scientists, experiments. Most of us have done... unpleasant things. All of us know too much.
The Empire keeps us because we're too valuable to kill--but it doesn't want us on its doorstep. Now do you understand?
I think I follow you. Now let's talk about the terrorists.
Let's move on.
Of course.
What makes you so valuable?
"Too valuable"?
My mind. My ability to see connections. Let me give you an example.
I understand more than you realize.
You have no idea.
Of course. And now we have business to discuss.
Watcher Two told me about you. You deserve to be here.
You are a criminal.
Watcher Two. We were part of the same eugenics program, she and I--both of us created to be superior minds.
You know that the Eagle's terrorists are using Nar Shaddaa as a supply hub. But I imagine you don't know their latest scheme.
The terror cell is on the verge of acquiring mass quantities of a new genetic modification serum: Cyclone. They plan to distribute it across the Eagle's network.
What's this serum do?
Cyclone?
You're certain?
Stray HoloNet transmissions. Murmurs in the underworld.
I don't intend to let any of them leave here alive.
I'll stop them.
Then you'd best move quickly.
Cyclone increases a user's speed and focus, transforming an average human into a natural assassin. It's also lethal--a minor defect.
We need to learn who created the serum and find their link to the terrorists. You must obtain a sample--a Cyclone dose or a user's blood specimen.
Where would I get a dose of Cyclone?
How do I do that?
Distribution is done anonymously, but Cyclone is available to the underworld. Gangsters are excellent test subjects.
You want me to go out and spill blood?
I'll make someone give it up.
I'd rather keep things quiet.
Maybe you want the Cyclone for yourself.
I don't trust your motives.
If I want to assassinate someone, I won't need a serum.
There's an augmentation shop in the Corellian Sector--a place people go for fast, dangerous modifications. Purchase the Cyclone there.
I can give you an injection to mimic the effects of long-term genetic damage. You'll be slower and weaker, but you'd make a convincing Cyclone buyer.
Go ahead. I'll play the part of a genetic wreck.
I need every edge I can get.
I assume the effects are temporary?
Slower and weaker?
It should last only last a short time--long enough for you to get to the shop.
I suggest you avoid excessive violence while affected, however. Now--do you want the injection or not?
All right--but this better not be a trick.
Fine.
You're brave, agent. Brave and trusting.
One moment, and I'll be done.
There. Now you should be on your way.
I'll take my chances without the injection.
I choose "not."
I'd rather pump myself full of toxic runoff.
No way, creep.
I'm not letting you inject me with anything.
I don't think so.
As you like.
Probably the smart choice. Too bad--wonder what he would've done to you.
Get to the shop. Get me my Cyclone or my blood. Then we find the link to your terrorist enemies.
You're not supposed to be here. Leave now.
I'll let you decide.
